title.text: German Dialect Identification Using Classifier Ensembles

abstractContent.text: In this paper we present the GDI classification entry to the second German Dialect Identification (GDI) shared task organized within the scope of the VarDial Evaluation Campaign 2018.
We present a system based on SVM classifier ensembles trained on characters and words.
The system was trained on a collection of speech transcripts of five Swiss-German dialects provided by the organizers.
The transcripts included in the dataset contained speakers from Basel, Bern, Lucerne, and Zurich.
Our entry in the challenge reached 62.03% F1 score and was ranked third out of eight teams.

introductionContent.text: Discriminating between dialects and language varieties is a challenging aspect of language identification that sparked interest in the NLP community in the past few years.
As evidenced in a recent survey, a number of papers have been published on this topic on dialects of Arabic () and Romanian (, and language varieties of English () and Portuguese (.

This challenge motivated the organization of a number of competitions such as the Discriminating between Similar Languages (DSL) shared tasks which included language varieties and similar languages (), the MGB challenge 2017 ( ) on Arabic, the PAN lab on author profiling, which in 2017 included varieties and dialects, and finally the first German Dialect Identification (GDI) shard task in 2017 ( ).
The GDI shared task 2017 preceded the second GDI shared task ( ) in which our team, GDI classification, participated.
In this paper we describe the GDI classification system trained to identify four dialects of (Swiss) German.
The GDI dataset included speech transcripts from speakers from Basel, Bern, Lucerne, and Zurich.
The system is based on an ensemble of multiple SVM classifiers trained on words and characters as features.
Our approach is inspired by the approach of, which was ranked first in the first edition of the GDI task and also performed well on identifying dialects of Arabic ().
We build on the experience of previous work of members of the GDI classification team improving a system that we have previously applied to a similar classification task, namely author profiling ().
